t: Job 34
Then*p Elihu continued, saying:
Hear*pn my words, you wise ones, and*ln listen to me, you knowledgeable ones.
Doesn’t*ln the ear test words as*ln the palate tastes food?
Let*ln us judge for ourselves what is right; let*ln us decide together what is good.
For*ln Job has declared, “I am righteous, yet*ln God has deprived me of justice.
Would*ln I lie about my case? My*ln wound is incurable, though*ln I am without transgression.”
What*ln man is like Job? He*ln drinks derision like water.
He*ln keeps company with evildoers and*ln walks with wicked men.
For*ln he has said, “A man gains nothing when*ln he becomes God’s friend.”
Therefore*pn listen to me, you men of understanding. It*ln is impossible for God to do wrong, and*ln for the Almighty to act unjustly.
For*ln he repays a person according to his deeds, and*ln he gives him what his conduct deserves.
Indeed,*ln it is true that God does not act wickedly and*ln the Almighty does not pervert justice.
Who*ln gave him authority over the earth? Who*ln put him in charge of the entire world?
If*ln he put his mind to it and*ln withdrew the spirit and breath he gave,
every*ln living thing would perish together and*ln mankind would return to the dust.
If*pn you have understanding, hear this; listen*ln to what I have to say.
Could*ln one who hates justice govern the world? Will*ln you condemn the mighty Righteous One,
who*ln says to a king, “Worthless man!” and*ln to nobles, “Wicked men!”?
God*ln is not partial to princes and*ln does not favor the rich over the poor, for*ln they are all the work of his hands.
They*ln die suddenly in the middle of the night; people*ln shudder, then pass away. Even*ln the mighty are removed without effort.
For*pn his eyes watch over a man’s ways, and*ln he observes all his steps.
There*ln is no darkness, no deep darkness, where*ln evildoers can hide.
God*ln does not need to examine a person further, that*ln one should approach him in court.
He*ln shatters the mighty without an investigation and*ln sets others in their place.
Therefore,*ln he recognizes their deeds and*ln overthrows them by night, and they are crushed.
In*ln full view of the public, he*ln strikes them for their wickedness,
because*ln they turned aside from following him and*ln did not understand any of his ways
but*ln caused the poor to cry out to him, and*ln he heard the outcry of the needy.
But*ln when God is silent, who can declare him guilty? When*ln he hides his face, who can see him? Yet*ln he watches over both individuals and nations,
so*ln that godless men should not rule or*ln ensnare the people.
Suppose*pn someone says to God, “I*ln have endured my punishment; I*ln will no longer act wickedly.
Teach*ln me what I cannot see; if*ln I have done wrong, I won’t do it again.”
Should*ln God repay you on your terms when*ln you have rejected his? You*ln must choose, not I! So*ln declare what you know.
Reasonable*ln men will say to me, along*ln with the wise men who hear me,
“Job*ln speaks without knowledge; his*ln words are without insight.”
If*ln only Job were tested to the limit, because*ln his answers are like those of wicked men.
For*ln he adds rebellion to his sin; he*ln scornfully claps in our presence, while*ln multiplying his words against God.
